shameless cash grab based off the books popularity.

childish. I'm not saying I agree with it, but that's the stigma of the 
hashtag.

books, so I may be a bit biased. In all honesty that comment was not my 
best. I just feel that a film shouldn't have pre-reading to get the most 
out of it. I agree that reading is something that drastically changes from 
person to person as it is affected that person's imagination, however 
movies to me feel a bit more sedimentary. A bad movie is bad you can really 
dissect it and figure it out. A bad book is kind of hard to define 
subtracting bad grammar and poor writing (things that usually get fixed in 
editing). For example I liked the Da Vinci Code, however its to my 
understanding that that writer (Dan Brown I believe) is not very good. At 
this point in development of this movie I can't really say whether its good 
or bad. I just have low expectations, because of how ,for lack of a better 
term, cash-grabby it feels.

I'm astonished at all the entirely negative reviews by men. In fact, I 
think it's the same kind of hate that men who are successful with women 
receive from other men (the jealous ones). Remember that this is a movie, 
and it's meant to be enjoyed by the appropriate audience, and not to be 
watched by people who don't care about erotic romance.

if that was the case, this would be widely popular by men and a great 
excuse for a man to go watch it with their "romantic" partner.

What this IS - IS a BDSM relationship, which are relationships based on 
TRUST and surrender from one party to another. And it is expected to be 
frowned upon by people who don't understand the fundamentals of that 
relationship.

I read all three books in the series, done in-depth character studies, and 
found this story to be popular because it hits the major fantasy points 
that dwell in the heads of A LOT of women. Let's face it, the way our 
society has gone, men have become weaker - and sometimes women miss a man 
who can roll the dice and show some self-control, as is demonstrated by the 
BDSM relationship - which requires a TON of control from the DOM/DOMME - in 
order to maximize the line between pain & pleasure for the submissive.

able to provide it with complete selflessness. It's not always about your 
own pleasure, but to cross the border into euphoria by creating unknown, 
yet pleasurable sensations.

Christian Grey struggles with a completely jacked up past, much like we all 
do. When I read this story, I could relate to some of the things he felt, 
some of his thoughts, and why he believed the things he did. And it took 
his love for a woman and her love for him, in order for him to drop false
